Submodules¶

app.scripts.python.normal_distribution_generator module¶

app.scripts.python.normal_distribution_generator.generate_samples(surveys: int = 10, sample_count: int = 10000, mean: float = 34, std: float = 30) → numpy.array[source]¶

Generates samples from a skewed normal distribution.

Note

If you use this sample generation, simply select pick up the elements and assign them to a label in sequence. In this case sample_count is just the number of samples I wish to take. See also generate_samples_extended().

Parameters

  • surveys – optional; The number of studies to be performed (default is 10).

  • sample_count – optional; The number of answers in each study. (default is 10000).

  • mean – optional; Where peak density will be found (default is 34.0).

  • std – optional; The standard deviation for the plotted normal distribution (default is 30.0).

Returns

The sampled bins.

app.scripts.python.normal_distribution_generator.generate_samples_extended(bin_count: int = 7001, sample_count: int = 7001) → Tuple[numpy.array, numpy.array][source]¶

Generates samples from a normal distribution.

Notes

A bin_count of 7001 represents all values between [30.00, 100.00] with 0.01 step, whereas a bin_count of 800001 would represents all values between [20.0000, 100.000] with 0.0001 step. To let matplotlib.skewnorm module define an automatic number of bins use bin_count=’auto’.

Parameters

  • bin_count – optional; (default is 7001).

  • sample_count – optional; The number of skewed results to be drawn. (default is 10000).

Returns

The sampled bins and respective frequencies.

app.scripts.python.normal_distribution_generator.plot_uptime_distribution(bin_count: Union[int, str] = 'auto', mean: float = 34.0, std: float = 30.0) → None[source]¶

Creates and draws a plot of the generated distribution

Parameters

  • bin_count – optional; The number of bins the plot should have (default is ‘auto’), i.e., matplotlib.pyplot module’s functions chooses a probably adequate bin count.

  • mean – optional; Where peak density will be found (default is 34.0).

  • std – optional; The standard deviation for the plotted normal distribution (default is 30.0).

app.scripts.python.skewed_distribution_generator module¶

app.scripts.python.skewed_distribution_generator.generate_skewed_samples(sample_count: int = 10000, skewness: float = - 90.0) → numpy.array[source]¶

Generates samples from a skewed normal distribution.

Note

If you use this sample generation, simply select pick up the elements and assign them to a label in sequence. In this case sample_count is just the number of samples I wish to take. See also generate_skewed_samples_extended().

Parameters

  • sample_count – optional; The number of skewed results to be drawn. (default is 10000).

  • skewness –

    optional; Where peak density will be found. Negative values make

    the plot left skewed, positive values make it right skewed ( default is -90.0).

Returns

The sampled bins.

app.scripts.python.skewed_distribution_generator.generate_skewed_samples_extended(bin_count: int = 7001, sample_count: int = 10000, skewness: float = - 90.0) → Tuple[numpy.array, numpy.array][source]¶

Generates samples from a skewed normal distribution.

Notes

A bin_count of 7001 represents all values between [30.00, 100.00] with 0.01 step, whereas a bin_count of 800001 would represents all values between [20.0000, 100.000] with 0.0001 step. To let matplotlib.skewnorm module define an automatic number of bins use bin_count=’auto’.

Parameters

  • bin_count – optional; (default is 7001).

  • sample_count – optional; The number of skewed results to be drawn. (default is 10000).

  • skewness –

    optional; Where peak density will be found. Negative values make

    the plot left skewed, positive values make it right skewed ( default is -90.0).

Returns

The sampled bins and respective frequencies.

app.scripts.python.skewed_distribution_generator.plot_uptime_distribution(bin_count: Union[int, str] = 'auto', skewness: float = - 90.0) → None[source]¶

Creates and draws a plot of the generated distribution

Parameters

  • bin_count – optional; The number of bins the plot should have (default is ‘auto’), i.e., matplotlib.pyplot module’s functions chooses a probably adequate bin count.

  • skewness – optional; Where peak density will be found. Negative values make the plot left skewed, positive values make it right skewed ( default is -90.0).
